lexUnit.name: stick.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: with obj. and adverbial of place put somewhere in a quick or careless way.

sentence.text: Satisfied that it was , he slammed it back into place and holstered the weapon , sticking his own pistol in the belt of his trousers .
It was like sticking pins into little wax models .
Then he stuck the cigar between his teeth and slowly sucked the life back into it .
He sticks one between his teeth but does n't light it -- just holds it there like a storeman 's pencil .
REAL firemen freed Joe Grey , four , after he stuck his head between railings at Scunthorpe , Humberside , because he wanted to be rescued by TV 's Fireman Sam .
Another policeman , fat and in uniform , comes forward and sticks his baton between us , separating us .
He stuck a finger through the bullet hole in his hat and spun the hat round a couple of times .
They did n't stick their cards through your letter box or advertise in the Yellow Pages , And very often they were unreliable people , demanding payment in advance or trying to blackmail you .
He was sitting at his desk on the second morning when Nikos stuck his head through the door .
Marie sticks her jeans in too -- she 's going to wear the dress under her coat .
Then she reclosed the book , stuck it back into the wastebin , stood the wastebin on his desk , and withdrew .
To assemble the flowers , secure several white petals together and stick a tiny ball of yellow coloured fondant on top .
Molly stuck her head out through the kitchen window , and looked around .
